unnormalised: ## Flash Sale Frenzy: Did Someone Say "Discount"?
normalised: Flash Sale Frenzy: Did Someone Say "Discount"?

unnormalised: Okay folks, let's be real. The words "Flash Sale" have the same effect on Indians as a free gol gappa stall at a Diwali mela. We descend. We conquer. And we probably end up with something we don't actually need, but hey, it was a *bargain*, right?
normalised: Okay folks, let's be real. The words "Flash Sale" have the same effect on Indians as a free gol gappa stall at a Diwali mela. We descend. We conquer. And we probably end up with something we don't actually need, but hey, it was a bargain, right?

unnormalised: Just last week, my Auntie Kamala from Bangalore saw "70% off designer sarees" on Meesho and practically broke the internet trying to order five. Turns out, the sarees looked more like something you’d use to dust the sq ft area in your storeroom, but she swore she'd find a use for them. "Maybe for Rekha's daughter's sangeet," she mused. Always the optimist, that Kamala!

unnormalised: These flash sales are everywhere these days, aren't they? Amazon, Flipkart, even Dr. Batra's offering deals on homeopathic remedies! You blink, and suddenly your inbox is flooded with subject lines like "HUGE SAVINGS! HURRY!" and "Limited Time Offer!". It's enough to make a person dizzy, especially if you've just had a large plate of biryani.

unnormalised: And let's not forget the panic. That frantic clicking, the heart pounding as you pray your size isn’t sold out, the near-miss heart attack when your payment fails. It’s basically a competitive sport. A very, very dangerous sport for your wallet.

unnormalised: I once saw a fight break out over a discounted pressure cooker at a Big Bazaar flash sale. Honestly, the drama rivaled a Bollywood film. Rs. 200 off, apparently, was worth risking life and limb.
normalised: I once saw a fight break out over a discounted pressure cooker at a Big Bazaar flash sale. Honestly, the drama rivaled a Bollywood film. Rupee two hundred off, apparently, was worth risking life and limb.

unnormalised: But hey, who are we kidding? We love it! The thrill of the chase, the feeling of accomplishment when you snag that coveted kurta for half price… it’s addictive! Just remember, folks, shop responsibly. Maybe. Or at least set a budget. And maybe invest in some good running shoes, just in case another pressure cooker situation arises. Jai Hind!
